definition[0]: a sudden bursting of a tyre
example[0]: I had a blow-out on the driver’s side.
definition[1]: a big expensive meal or large social occasion
example[1]: We went for a real blow-out to celebrate.
definition[2]: an easy victory over someone in a game
definition[3]: a sudden uncontrolled escape of oil or gas from a well
definition[4]: when a business fails or a financial market falls very quickly
example[2]: Bull markets always end in a speculative blowout.
definition[5]: a very successful period of time for sales or profits
example[3]: Microsoft’s performance was slightly better than expectations, but it wasn’t a blowout quarter.
definition[6]: in oil exploration, when pressure from under the ground causes oil to flow in an uncontrolled way
example[4]: a platform blowout that spilled thousands of barrels of oil into Santa Barbara Channel
